awd_titl_txt: IUSE/PFE:RED: Clemson University: Learning Teams and Innovation Ventures for Adaptable Training in Engineering (CULTIVATE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Academic departments are complex, knowledge-intensive social systems of interacting and interdependent agents (e.g., students, faculty, and staff). Complexity theorists describe such systems as social networks that are continuously reconstructed as agents within the network interact and influence one another. Complexity leadership theorists develop strategies for managing such social systems to guide this dynamic and to improve the social network and its agents. When effectively led, these social systems can create a shared vision and collective impetus for action, producing new patterns of behavior or new modes of operating. Guided by these principles, this NSF IUSE/PFE:RED project aims to transform the academic culture of the Glenn Department of Civil Engineering at Clemson University so that the faculty and students of the program can better meet the changing societal needs of the 21st century. Few, if any, studies have explored emergent behavior in complex, dynamic social networks and the capacity of these networks to initiate and sustain change in departmental cultures; informed research on the emergence of innovative ideas toward change; evaluated the influence of social networks on innovative capacity of individual members; or provided a useful case for academic departments looking to make similar transformations. Therefore, this study has the potential to make a significant contribution to the literature as it focuses on understanding and communicating the underlying dynamics that explain why and how change occurs in a social system, how continuous change can be sustained, and how similar change strategies can be implemented elsewhere. Validated at Clemson, this change framework is to be disseminated to other engineering departments nationwide, including 60 ABET-accredited civil engineering departments. Hence, the potential societal impacts of the project include a cultural shift in civil engineering education across the nation to produce a new breed of civil engineers capable of creating solutions for 21st-century problems that are posing unprecedented threats to our society.

With the aim of creating a low-cost, scalable, replicable academic change framework informed by complexity leadership theory, this project undertakes three tactics. Tactic 1 involves transforming our curriculum to create new faculty/student interactions and interdependencies via heterogeneous teams to create an environment ripe for the emergence of innovative ideas. This tactic aims to create a curricular scaffold that weaves the coursework both vertically and horizontally through carefully designed, socially-relevant, practically meaningful problem statements with input from project stakeholders and oversight from government partners. This tactic is envisioned to disrupt the status quo and facilitate new forms of interaction among students, faculty, and professionals. Tactic 2 involves transforming the departmental structure and culture to promote innovation through a collective impetus for change resulting from new faculty-faculty interactions and dependencies. The project team uses a soft-wired organizational structure to create conditions conducive for the emergence of complex, dynamic collaborations among faculty to enable innovation and rapid adaptation. Rather than organizing around the solutions faculty can offer, soft-wiring enables the faculty to organize around the societal problems they can solve, leading to flexible, hybrid teaching formats. Tactic 3 involves tactful utilization of discomfort and tension in Discomfort Zone gatherings to create a shared vision for transformation among all engineering departments at Clemson. The intellectual merit of this project focuses on creating an academic culture of innovation and adaptability, which is a prerequisite for sustainable change. The use of complexity leadership theory in an academic setting and the collection of longitudinal data on the emergent outcomes it predicts fill an important knowledge gap in the pertinent literature.  This project is jointly funded by the Division of Undergraduate Education; the Division of Engineering Education and Centers, the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation; the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems; and the Division of Industrial Innovation and Partnerships; reflecting the alignment of this project with the respective goals of the divisions and their programs.

por.por_cntn:
At Clemson, Glenn Department of Civil Engineering’s overarching goal for the NSF Revolutionizing Engineering Departments (RED) project was to transform the department to be responsive to rapidly evolving complex challenges of highly interconnected infrastructure systems to meet society's most pressing needs. The research took a multipronged approach with three interconnected goals:

  • Curricular Transformation for Innovation - Establish an inclusive and collaborative environment to promote innovation, creative problem-solving, and social responsiveness among students by weaving hands-on projects throughout the curriculum.
  • Cultural Transformation for Adaptability - Adopt flexible departmental structures to rapidly adapt to meet changing needs and develop Faculty to become enabling leaders who foster collective impetus for innovative change through shared values.
  • Community Transformation for Shared Vision - Establish a shared vision for educational innovation across engineering departments at Clemson University and nationally.

After five years of development and piloting, the Glenn Department of Civil Engineering faculty approved a dramatic change to the Civil Engineering undergraduate curriculum. The change targeted weaknesses identified by alumni and industry partners, including a lack of experiential learning; disconnects between technical knowledge, practical application, and societal impacts; need for professional skill development - mainly associated with oral and written communication; and inconsistent use of technical tools. The resulting curriculum change, the Arch Initiatives, disrupted the status quo and facilitated new interaction between students, faculty, and industry partners. The arch symbolizes the significant components of the program. In the sophomore year, students take Springer courses, which provide the foundation for successful teamwork, professional ethics, critical thinking, design processes, and professional formation as a civil engineer. These courses are named after the first blocks laid in constructing an arch. The studio courses occur in the middle years of the program and represent the arch blocks. Studio courses allow students to take what they learn in Springer courses (i.e., communication and teamwork) and apply them in more advanced courses in the context of the technical subject matter they are learning. Like most engineering programs, the Arch Initiatives ends with a culminating design experience - the Keystone course.

Program evaluators asked students to reflect on their experience in the Springer courses and students attributed five outcomes to these courses including the development of their engineering identity, improving their understanding of the civil engineering discipline, fostering their engagement in the practice of civil engineering, positively affecting their future engineering career goals, and gaining connections with others in the field. 

Our cultural transformation was grounded in the theory of complexity leadership. Complexity leadership theory focuses on enabling adaptability and generating an adaptive response in the overall network.  When pressure is applied to a network, there will be a push for change, which is often met with a push for stability.  This results in conflicting thoughts and ideas. If the different individuals in the network can work through that conflict and make connections, they will create a collaborative space where adaptive solutions can be conceived. Teams often give up when they meet opposing views, but these opposing views are essential to generating solutions that will be successful across the organization. What we learned from studying complexity leadership theory is now embodied in two of our core departmental values:

  • Inclusive Community - We engage diverse perspectives with open communication and encouraging attitudes.
  • Continuous Improvement & Innovation - Improvement efforts are fundamental to how we assess ourselves as individuals and as a department. 

We proudly display our values in the department and use them to drive our collective decision-making.

The final activity for our project involved hosting civil engineering program faculty from across the nation in conjunction with our premier professional society – the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) for the 2023 ASCE Engineering Education Summit. The three-day event drew 110 attendees from 52 universities across the country.  Three NSF program directors and ASCE leadership joined a host of speakers in 24 interactive workshop sessions. One plenary session highlighting the five NSF RED programs in civil engineering departments was repeated at the ASCE Department Heads Convention last year.  Following these two events, the ASCE Committee on Education (COE) and the Innovation in Civil Engineering Education (ICEE) Working Group established a new standing session on engineering education at the ASCE Annual Convention. In our profession, there is one persistent argument against curriculum change: ABET accreditation. The Glenn Department of Civil Engineering at Clemson University hosted our ABET program evaluation at the conclusion of our NSF RED project.  Our evaluator closed his comments by stating that our program, “can be a model of innovation for other civil engineering programs.”
